data.text: RT @alvaroortiz1968: Super paper 👉 Why People visit Fast Food Food places? What to do?A 62 Million visit Analysis gives the answer by @alex…

Interventions targeting areas combining these features could have 1.7x - 4x larger effects than those that alter food swamps/deserts. For example, we find that interventions in areas related to shopping, traveling, or work could be more efficient than around home.

where i) the prevalence of FFO is the highest,i i) most decisions about food outlet visits are made, and most importantly, and more importantly where iii) visitors’ decisions are most susceptible to the environment.

Using our results, we investigate multiple intervention strategies for food environments to promote reduced FFO visits. We find that optimal locations for intervention are a combination of three factors:

Using a semi-causal framework and various natural experiments on high-resolution mobility data, we find a strong effect of the quality of mobile food environment on going to fast food outlet (FFO). 10% more FFO in an area increase odds of people visiting FFO by approximately 20%.

Contrary to the general belief, we find that most visits to fast-food outlets (FFO) happen far away from home. Thus focusing on static food environments around home, such as food deserts and swamps, miss the mobile food environments people are exposed to.

📢New paper: "Effect of mobile food environments on fast food visits" in @NatureComms. Using large-scale data and 62Million visits to food places we investigate what drives people to visit fast food places where they happen. And that is well beyond homes!
